<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The writer then, came to birth with difficulty in England:</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the unsayable. He is writing, for the printing press has</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">unspecialised, undifferentiated. <del>There is a passage in</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>The eye was</del> <del>For one</del> <del>He was, seeing;</del> The artist</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">is not wholly writer, wholly musician, or wholly</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">painter. It seems possible that the great English art</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">may not be the art of words. His</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">eye <del>was</del> <add place="above">is</add> stimulated <del>in that empty world</del>, by the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">colours <add place="above">of the</add> of the clothing. His ear <del>was</del></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><del>stimulated</del> by the sound of <add place="above">music</add> words. <quote rend="inline" source="#">"Pritchard"</quote> said</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-aclif" key="Clifford, Ann">Lady Ann Clifford</rs> <quote rend="inline" source="#">read aloud <del>They</del> The Faery Queen..."</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">England was given substance & sharpness of the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">speaking voice. And <del>the</del> music gave lilt &</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">rhythm, melody to the spoken word.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote rend="inline" source="#">"Hardly one lighter or boat in three that had the</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote rend="inline" source="#">goods of a home in it <del>"</del> but there was a</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote rend="inline" source="#">pair of virginals in it"</quote> <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-spep">Pepys</rs> observed, in 1666,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">when the people of London were loading their</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">goods onto boats in the great fire. His</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">world then was full of undifferentiated words:</l>
